Waiting for the instructor to move on to the next question.

Sudoku is played on a grid of 6x6 or 9x9 spaces. Each row, column and square needs to be filled out with the numbers 1-6 or 1-9, without repeating any numbers within the row, column or square. While solving a Sudoku question, by looking at the numbers in the same rows, columns and squares, the numbers that cannot be found in the spaces are determined and the possibilities are reduced. For example, if 8 out of 9 numbers cannot be placed in a space, the remaining 1 number can be placed precisely.

In Mine Sweeper game, the numbers given show how many diamonds their neighbors have. While solving a Mine Sweeper question, the first thing to look for is clues that have as many neighbors as the number written in them. Clues that have as many neighbors as the number written in them may not be found in every question or may be insufficient to reach a solution. What needs to be looked for in these cases is the common effects of the diamonds which will be placed on the neighbors of the clues, on the other clues.

The aim of the Loop game is to draw a path that will fill all empty boxes, will not cross over itself, pass through each box once and form a single closed shape when completed. When solving the Loop question, first of all, corners are found. If 2 of the 4 neighbors (horizontal and vertical neighbors) of any square are closed, a path is drawn to its other two neighbors. This process is continued until no more corners can be drawn. In addition, another method that should be used is to utilize the single-closed-path rule. For example, if there are 2 directions for the path to go in a box and a small closed shape is formed when continuing from one of them, the other path should be taken.

In the Number Puzzle game, the numbers on the right show how many of the numbers in that row are included in the answer. Numbers with a \'+\' sign next to them indicate that the numbers in that row are in the same column in the answer. Those with a \'-\' sign next to them indicate that the numbers in that row are in a different column in the answer. For example, in a line that says \'+1 -2\' on the right side, it can be deduced that 3 of the numbers are in the answer and 1 of them is in the correct place and 2 of them are in the wrong place.

The aim of the Word Tour game is to find words in the table according to the number of letters given. In this game; it is necessary to draw a path starting from the word with the fewest letters and moving between the boxes horizontally, vertically or diagonally and ending at the last letter of the word with the most letters. In addition, each box should be used only once and no empty boxes should be left.

In the Pyramid game, the numbers in the boxes must be the sum or difference of the numbers in the 2 boxes below them. In addition, the same number cannot be placed more than once in a row and consecutive numbers cannot be placed in adjacent boxes. All empty boxes must be filled in accordance with these rules.
Welcome to Mine Sweeper Tutorial. You can take part in the solving process by tapping the blinking boxes throughout the tutorial.
"In Mine Sweeper, number clues show how many of their neighbours have diamonds. "
The first thing to look for when solving is the clues that have as many neighbors as the number written in them.
As seen in the example, clues with 4 written in it have only 4 neighbors. These neighbors can definitely be filled with diamonds
As you can notice, 2 of the 4 diamonds we have placed are the neighbors of the clue with the number 2 in it.
So the clue with 2 in it has got all the diamonds it should have and its other neighbors cannot have diamonds. Crosses are placed on these neighbors by switching to the cross by pressing switch box.
Clues that have as many neighbors as the number written in them may not be found in every question or may be insufficient to reach a solution.
What needs to be looked at in these cases is the common effects of diamonds placed on the neighbors of the clues on the other clues.
For example these 2 clues have 3 neighbors and 2 of these 3 boxes must be diamonds.
As you can see, these 3 boxes are also neighbors of the clue with 2 in it. So the 2 diamonds in these 3 boxes affect it as well.
Since there will definitely be 2 diamonds in these 3 gray-coloured neighbors, the other neighbors cannot have diamonds. Crosses should be placed in these neighbors.
The clue with 1 in it on the right has only one empty neighbor left. A diamond is put to the last empty neighbor by switching to the diamond from the switch box.
One of the neighbors of the clue marked in green has a diamond. So one of the remaining 2 neighbors has to have a diamond.
The clue marked in green and containing 1 must also have a diamond in one of its 2 neighbors.
So there are 2 diamonds in total in these 4 boxes.
The 2 diamonds in these 4 boxes also affect the clue marked in green. Therefore, a cross should be placed to the remaining neighbor of the clue with 2 in it.
The clue marked in green with a 1 in it has only one neighbor left. This neighbor should also receive a diamond.
The clue marked in green with a 3 in it has a diamond in one of its neighbors. The remaining 2 neighbors should also receive diamonds.
You have come to the end of this tutorial.üèÅ You can exit with the help of the back button at the top left or return to the previous steps with the arrow keys.
Do you want to log out of your account?
Welcome to the Loop Puzzle Tutorial. You can take part in the solving process by drawing lines as shown in the animations throughout the tutorial.
In Loop Puzzle, the purpose is to draw a closed path which does not cross itself and passes through each white box.
While solving Loop Puzzle, you should use 2 basic techniques: Finding corners and edges, being careful not to form a small closed path.
"Finding corner and edges means that, if two neighbors of a box is closed (cannot draw a line to them) you should draw a line to the remaining 2 neighbors forming a corner or edge. "

For example, the top and left neighbors of the box on the top left is closed, which means there cannot be a path drawn towards these neighbors. Therefore, you should draw a line towards bottom and right neighbors, forming a corner.
Like shown in the previous step, draw corners/edges into other boxes that have 2 closed neighbors.
In the 2nd solving technique, you should obstruct the formation of a small closed path which do not pass from each box on the grid.
For example in the box which is marked red, path can go either upwards or to the right. If it goes upwards, a small closed path will be formed. Therefore, the path should go to the right.
Like shown in the previous step, follow the animations and draw suitable lines using the method of obstructing the formation of small closed paths.
You have come to the end of this tutorial.üèÅ You can exit with the help of the back button at the top left or return to the previous steps with the arrow keys.
Your opponent solved all of the puzzles.
Welcome to Number Puzzle Tutorial. You can take part in the solving process by tapping the blinking boxes throughout the tutorial.
In the Number Puzzle game, the numbers on the right show how many of the numbers on that row are included in the answer.

Numbers with a \'+\' sign next to them indicate that the digit or numbers in that row are in the same column in the answer, while those with a \'-\' sign next to them indicate that they are in a different column.
For example, in the answer on the row with the marked clue, there are 2 numbers whose location is correct, and 1 number whose location is incorrect.
The first clues to be considered while solving Number Puzzle are the clues with \'+\'. If a number is in different places on two different rows with \'+\', that number can be eliminated.

For example, rows with marked clues have the number 0 in common, and both clues have only \'+\'. The number 0 is eliminated because it is in different digits and cannot be in two digits at the same time.

Next, the total number of clues should be checked. In the example this number is 1+3+2+1=7. That is, from 7 clues, 4 numbers will be formed. This indicates that some numbers must be common across rows.

If the total number of clues is a medium-high number for a 4x4 Number puzzle question, such as 7, the numbers common to multiple rows should be used. If this number was less, it would be possible to go from non-common numbers.

As can be seen in the example, the number 5 is common in three rows. You can make it shaded green by pressing this number. Then we can eliminate the remaining numbers from the rows that fulfill the clue number.
In the first row, the clue is +1 and the number 5 are colored green. Therefore, the number 5 is in the answer and its place is correct. 5 should be written in the last digit of the answer.

When the numbers are eliminated, there would be 2 numbers left that could be on the 2nd row, and since there are 2 numbers left in the clue, these numbers will definitely be included in the answer. These numbers are marked in green.
It can be said that the location of the number 9 marked with green in the 3rd row (because the clue is +2) is correct. 9 should be written in the third digit of the answer.

It is seen that the place of the number 5 marked with green in the second rowis correct and the place of the number 9 is wrong. So only +1 left from the clue. Therefore, the location of the number 2 is correct and it is in the first digit.

Only the number in the 2nd digit remains. In the 3rd line, the place of the number 9 is correct and +1 is left from the clue. Since the blank digit is only the 2nd digit, the number 8 in the 3rd line should be in the answer.

When the solution ends, the answer is found as 2895. Number Puzzle questions can generally be solved by these methods. However, if the solver gets stuck in one place, it is possible to go by trial and error from the numbers that are common in the most rows.
You have come to the end of this tutorial.üèÅ You can exit with the help of the back button at the top left or return to the previous steps with the arrow keys.
Welcome to Pyramid Tutorial. You can take part in the solving process by tapping the blinking boxes throughout the tutorial.

In the pyramid game, the solver is asked to fill the empty boxes in the pyramid in a regular way. The rules of the game are as follows: 1. The sum or difference of every adjacent number pair is equal to the number above it.

2. There can be no repeating numbers in the same row. 3. Numbers next to each other cannot be consecutive. Pyramid questions are solved by paying attention to these 3 rules. The most common method used when solving a pyramid is the elimination method.
In the example, a 3-row pyramid question is given. For example, we can start with the empty box on the bottom row of this pyramid.
Clues 4 and 7 are given in the bottom line. Based on the rules of non-consecutiveness and non-repetition, it can be said that the empty box cannot take the numbers 3,4,5,6,7 and 8.

Therefore, only the numbers 1,2 or 9 can be written in this box. These possibilities can be noted by switching to the note-taking mode at the bottom right. Then, the difference and the sum of these probabilities and clues can be taken individually.

For example, the possibilities 1,2 and 9 reveal the possibilities (3,5), (2,6) and 5 in the box above it, respectively. Likewise, in the box next to it, the possibilities (6.8), (5.9) and 2 are formed, respectively.
These possibilities can be found in mind or noted down. As a final step, it should be determined which of these possibilities, the difference or the sum, gives the number at the top, namely 5.

When the probabilities are examined, it can be seen that the difference of the numbers 3 and 8 is 5. Therefore, probability 1, which gives these probabilities, is also true. When checks are made, it is seen that the pyramid complies with the rules.
You have come to the end of this tutorial.üèÅ You can exit with the help of the back button at the top left or return to the previous steps with the arrow keys.
